title: How to Get Started in Blackwork Embroidery

steps.headline: Understand the technique behind blackwork.
steps.description: Blackwork is created using a "stabbing motion". This action takes the thread from front to back and back to front. It is absolutely essential to avoid gliding across the fabric.

steps.headline: Choose an easy pattern to begin with.
steps.description: When you first start blackwork embroidery, be sure to choose something simple for practice purposes. The first attempts will likely not provide the appearance you're wanting but keep trying.

steps.headline: Use even weave fabric.
steps.description: Blackwork must be exact and even; uneven fabrics will skew this and create an unbalance embroidery that doesn't provide a pleasing appearance.

steps.headline: Check that the thread you intend to use fits the weave of the fabric.
steps.description: Do not use thread that is larger than the count of the fabric. If you try to do this, the larger holes will create a distortion, introducing undesirable unevenness to the design.

steps.headline: Choose the correct needle for undertaking blackwork embroidery.
steps.description: The best needle is a blunt tapestry needle because it will be less likely to split the even weave threads. Note that the risk of splitting is a concern to be wary of as you undertake blackwork embroidery.

steps.headline: Tie a waste knot to start a new thread.
steps.description: A waste knot involves leaving a knot on the surface of the fabric, a short distance from the starting point of the embroidery.

steps.headline: Help wikiHow improve its articles on embroidery.
steps.description: This article is merely about preparing for blackwork embroidery. wikiHow now needs lots more articles on the actual stitches involved in blackwork (with pictures where possible), as well as copyright free patterns.
